info.name: 18.4.2 Oracle Identity Cloud Service Factor Verification API
info.description:
This collection provides step-by-step REST calls to complete factor verification of the Default factor and the backup factor.

Factor verification is a 2-step process. You first need to ask Oracle Identity Cloud Service to initiate the verification of the factor. After initiating, the client needs to then verify the factor by passing the otpCode, security answer, by accepting the PUSH notification on the OMA app, or using a bypass code.

item.name: Authentication Factor Verification
Fetch Enrolled Factors of a User
Get Enrolled Factors for a User by userGUID

request.description:
You may need to first get a list of factors that the user in enrolled in before initiating factor enrollment. You can search for this information two ways: by specifying the userGUID or using a filter with the user name.

This example shows you how to get the list of factors enrolled by the user using the userGUID in the request.

Since every user is uniquely identified in Oracle Identity Cloud Service using the userGUID, the user needs to provide the userGUID when getting their enrolled factors.

However, a user may not be aware of their userGUID. To support such cases, a user can make a request to get their enrolled factors by using a filter with the user name.

See the other request example included in this folder for an example of filter using the user name.

The response contains the userGUID, the preferred factor, and the enrolled factor details.

response.name: Success Response to Get Enrolled Factors for a User by userGUID

item.name: Get Enrolled Factors for a User by User Name

request.description:
You may need to first get a list of factors that the user in enrolled in before initiating factor enrollment. You can search for this information two ways: by specifying the userGUID or using a filter with the user name.

This example shows you how to get the list of factors enrolled by the user using the user name in the request.

Since every user is uniquely identified in Oracle Identity Cloud Service using the userGUID, the user needs to provide the userGUID when getting their enrolled factors.

However, a user may not be aware of their userGUID. To support such cases, a user can make a request to get their enrolled factors by using a filter with the user name.

The response contains the userGUID, the preferred factor, and the enrolled factor details.

item.description:
Since every user is uniquely identified in Oracle Identity Cloud Service using the userGUID, the user needs to provide the userGUID when getting their enrolled factors.

However, a user may not be aware of their userGUID. To support such cases, a user can make a request to get their enrolled factors by using a filter with the user name.

The response contains the userGUID, the preferred factor, and the enrolled factor details.

item.name: Initiate & Verify the Preferred Factor
Step 1: Initiate Verification of the Preferred Factor

request.description:
This step initiates the verification of a user's preferred factor. If you need to use the verify factor API without getting the userGUID, you can provide a user unique id such as user name as the userId. The userIdType in the request indicates what type of credential the user is passing as the value for the userId. The following userIdType values are accepted:

    USER_GUID

    USER_NAME

The userId attribute contains the actual value of the user credential that is passed. 

In the response, the requestId value is the unique identifier generated for this request. Include the requestId in every subsequent call to complete factor verification. The requestState contains contextual data needed to process the request.

response.name: TOTP Reponse to Step 1: Initiate Verification on the Default Factor

request.description:
If the factor is SMS/EMAIL/TOTP and the user hasn't received the TOTP, the client can request that the server to send it again. Every SMS/EMAIL/TOTP sent increments the user's MFA login attempt count.

After the user meets their maximum login attempts, the user account is locked if the user doesn't make a successful login after requesting the TOTP.

The response contains the requestId and the requestState needed for the next request.

response.name: SMS and EMAIL Success Response to Step 1a: Resend TOTP

request.description:
This step verifies the factor by passing the otpCode or accepting a PUSH notification on the Oracle Mobile Authenticator app. If the factor is SMS/EMAIL/TOTP, then the client must include the following attributes:

    otpCode: the code received by the user on their device

    requestState: received in the Step 1 response

    requestID: received in the Step 1 response

The response contains the status of the verification and the cause if it fails.

response.name: Success Response to Verify the SMS/EMAIL/TOTP/BYPASSCODE Factor

item.name: Step 2: Verify the Security Question Factor

request.description:
This step verifies the factor by passing the securityQuestions id/answer map. This is an array since you can mandate that a user answer more than one question while verifying MFA. The client must include the following in the request:

    requestState: received in the Step 1 response

    securityQuestions id/answers: defined by the user during enrollment

The response contains the status of the verification and the cause if it fails.

response.name: Success Reponse to Step 2: Verify the Security Question Factor

item.description:
Factor verification is a 2-step process. You first need to ask Oracle Identity Cloud Service to initiate the verification of the factor. After initiating, the client needs to then verify the factor by passing the otpCode, security answer, by accepting the PUSH notification on the OMA app, or using a bypass code.

Use the example requests in this folder to initiate and verify the preferred factor as well as verify the PUSH factor by polling for the Push Notification Verification Request.

Since the PUSH notification must be accepted/rejected by the user on the Oracle Mobile Authenticator App, there is a "polling" API for the client to use if the user has acted on this notification.

item.name: Initiate & Verify a Backup Factor
Step 1: Initiate Verification of Backup Factor (SMS,EMAIL,TOTP)

request.description:
This step initiates the verification of a user's backup factor. 
In the request, if you need to use the verify factor API without getting the userGUID, you can provide a user unique id such as user name as the userId. The userIdType in the request indicates what type of credential the user is passing as the value for the userId. The following userIdType values are accepted:

    USER_GUID

    USER_NAME

The userId attribute contains the actual value of the user credential that is passed.

The client must provide both the factorId and the method in the request. To obtain a list of enrolled factors and their IDs for a user, see the Fetch Enrolled Factors for a User folder.

In the response, the requestId value is the unique identifier generated for this request. Include the requestId in every subsequent call to complete factor verification. The requestState contains contextual data needed to process the request.

response.name: SMS Success Response to Initiate Verification of Backup Factor

This step verifies the backup factor. The client must include the following attributes:

    otpCode: the code received by the user on their device

    requestState: received in the Step 1 response

    requestID: received in the Step 1 response


The response contains the status of the verification and the cause if it fails.

item.name: Step 1: Initiate Verification of Backup Factor (BypassCode)

request.description:
This step initiates the verification of a user's BYPASS CODE as the backup factor.

If the user doesn't want to use the default factor or their backup factor, the user has the option to provide the "factorId" and "method" as BYPASS CODE to indicate that they want to use a previously generated BYPASS code as the factor.

In the request, if you need to use the verify factor API without getting the userGUID, you can provide a user unique id such as user name as the userId. The userIdType in the request indicates what type of credential the user is passing as the value for the userId. The following userIdType values are accepted:

    USER_GUID

    USER_NAME

The userId attribute contains the actual value of the user credential that is passed.

The client must provide both the factorId and the method (BYPASSCODE) in the request. To obtain a list of enrolled factors and their IDs for a user, see the Fetch Enrolled Factors for a User folder.

In the response, the requestId value is the unique identifier generated for this request. Include the requestId in every subsequent call to complete factor verification. The requestState contains contextual data needed to process the request.

response.name: Bypass Code Success Response to Initiate Verification of Backup Factor

request.description:
This step verifies BYPASS CODE as the backup factor. The client must include the following attributes:

    requestState: received in the Step 1 response

    bypassCode: a code previously generated by either the user or an administrator on the user's behalf.

The response contains the status of the verification and the cause if it fails.

response.name: Bypass Code Success Response to Step 2: Verify the Backup Factor

item.name: Step 1: Initiate Verification of Backup Factor (Security Questions)

request.description:
This step initiates the verification of a user's backup factor (Security Questions). 

In the request, if you need to use the verify factor API without getting the userGUID, you can provide a user unique id such as user name as the userId. The userIdType in the request indicates what type of credential the user is passing as the value for the userId. The following userIdType values are accepted:

    USER_GUID

    USER_NAME

The userId attribute contains the actual value of the user credential that is passed.

The client must provide both the factorId and the method (SECURITY_QUESTIONS) in the request. To obtain a list of enrolled factors and their IDs for a user, see the Fetch Enrolled Factors for a User folder.

In the response, the requestId value is the unique identifier generated for this request. Include the requestId in every subsequent call to complete factor verification. The requestState contains contextual data needed to process the request.

response.name: Security Questions Success Response to Initiate Verification of Backup Factor

item.name: Step 2: Verify the Backup Factor (Security Questions)

request.description:
This step verifies the backup factor (SECURITY_QUESTIONS). The client must include the following attributes:

    requestState: received in the Step 1 response

     securityQuestions id/answers: defined by the user during enrollment

The response contains the status of the verification and the cause if it fails.

response.name: Security Questions Success Response to Step 2: Verify the Backup Factor

request.description:
Use this example to poll for the Push Notification Verification Request.

Since the PUSH notification must be accepted/rejected by the user on the Oracle Mobile Authenticator App, we provide a "polling" api for the client to use if the user has acted on this notification.

response.name: Pending Response to Step 2: Verify the Backup Factor (PUSH)

item.description:
Use the examples in this folder to initiate and verify a backup factor.

If the user doesn't want to use the default factor, the user has the option to provide the "factorId" and "method" to indicate that they want to use one of their backup factors.

Factor verification is a 2-step process.

1. You need to ask Oracle Identity Cloud Service to initiate the verification of the factor. 
2. After initiating, the client needs to then verify the factor by passing the otpCode, security answer, or accepting a PUSH notification on the OMA app, or using a bypasss code.
